docs.abstract: Days after Google, Facebook and Apple removed Infowars content, the app from the right-wing conspiracy site has surged in downloads.
docs.snippet: Days after Google, Facebook and Apple removed Infowars content, the app from the right-wing conspiracy site has surged in downloads.
docs.lead_paragraph: Just days after Google, Facebook and Apple purged videos and podcasts from the right-wing conspiracy site Infowars from their sites, the Infowars app has become one of the hottest in the country.

headline.main: Tech Companies Banned Infowars. Now, Its App Is Trending.
headline.print_headline: Infowars App Is Trending As Platforms Ban Content

docs.abstract: The elimination leaves Mr. Jones with a dearth of avenues to reach a mainstream audience.
docs.snippet: The elimination leaves Mr. Jones with a dearth of avenues to reach a mainstream audience.
docs.lead_paragraph: The bad news for Alex Jones, the notorious internet conspiracy theorist, keeps coming.

headline.main: Alex Jones’s Infowars Is Removed From Apple’s App Store

docs.abstract: On the same day the company announced it had purged domestic sources of disinformation, it said it had blocked two companies, one of them with Russian government clients.
docs.snippet: On the same day the company announced it had purged domestic sources of disinformation, it said it had blocked two companies, one of them with Russian government clients.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On the same day Facebook announced that it had carried out its biggest purge yet of American accounts peddling disinformation, the company quietly made another revelation: It had removed 66 accounts, pages and apps linked to Russian firms that build facial recognition software for the Russian government.

headline.main: Facebook Says Russian Firms ‘Scraped’ Data, Some for Facial Recognition
headline.print_headline: Included in Facebook Purge: Data Collectors From Russia

docs.abstract: When Facebook and YouTube booted Mr. Jones, the internet provocateur, last month, Twitter did not. On Thursday, it joined them.
docs.snippet: When Facebook and YouTube booted Mr. Jones, the internet provocateur, last month, Twitter did not. On Thursday, it joined them.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple, Facebook and Google’s YouTube mostly barred Alex Jones, the right-wing provocateur and creator of the conspiracy theorist website Infowars, last month for propagating hate speech. Twitter did not.

headline.main: Twitter Bars Alex Jones and Infowars, Citing Harassing Messages
headline.print_headline: Twitter, Citing Harassment, Bars Agitator and His Website

byline.original: By Kate Conger and Jack Nicas

docs.abstract: Caught in the trade fight between Washington and Beijing, Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has become something of an envoy while trying to protect the company’s business in China.
docs.snippet: Caught in the trade fight between Washington and Beijing, Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has become something of an envoy while trying to protect the company’s business in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, may be the leader of the world’s most valuable public company, but lately he has had to act a lot like the tech industry’s top diplomat.

headline.main: In China Trade War, Apple Worries It Will Be Collateral Damage

byline.original: By Jack Nicas and Paul Mozur

docs.abstract: Apple is using its five-day software conference to address two themes hovering over the tech industry: an erosion of privacy and smartphone addiction.
docs.snippet: Apple is using its five-day software conference to address two themes hovering over the tech industry: an erosion of privacy and smartphone addiction.
docs.lead_paragraph: ■ Apple is adding tools to help get your information addiction under control.

headline.main: Apple’s WWDC 2018 Live: Apple Still Wants to Be Different
headline.print_headline: At Conference, Apple Tells Developers It Still Wants to Be Different

byline.original: By Jack Nicas, Brian X. Chen and Farhad Manjoo

docs.abstract: Less than a week after the European Union fined Google $5.1 billion for abusing its dominance in smartphones, the tech giant still posted big profits.
docs.snippet: Less than a week after the European Union fined Google $5.1 billion for abusing its dominance in smartphones, the tech giant still posted big profits.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — European authorities took their best swing, but it appears that Google hardly felt it.

headline.main: Google Shrugs Off $5.1 Billion Fine With Another Big Quarter
headline.print_headline: Hit by $5.1 Billion Fine, But Still Google Surges

docs.abstract: Boston Dynamics often makes a splash with videos of its anthropomorphic robots. But after years of work, it is not clear who would buy them or what they would be used for.
docs.snippet: Boston Dynamics often makes a splash with videos of its anthropomorphic robots. But after years of work, it is not clear who would buy them or what they would be used for.
docs.lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Mass. — Moving like a large dog, knees bent and hips swaying, the robot walked across a parking lot and into a rain puddle.

headline.main: These Robots Run, Dance and Flip. But Are They a Business?
headline.print_headline: For Sale: One Robot In Search Of a Job

byline.original: By Cade Metz and Max Aguilera-Hellweg

docs.abstract: Technology firms move to curb one of the loudest voices in conspiracy theories, fueling further debate over free speech online.
docs.snippet: Technology firms move to curb one of the loudest voices in conspiracy theories, fueling further debate over free speech online.
docs.lead_paragraph: Top technology companies erased most of the posts and videos on their services from Alex Jones, the internet’s notorious conspiracy theorist, thrusting themselves into a fraught debate over their role in regulating what can be said online.

headline.main: Alex Jones and Infowars Content Is Removed From Apple, Facebook and YouTube
headline.print_headline: Tech Giants Push Infowars Off Digital Soapbox

docs.abstract: Amazon announced its plans for a second headquarters a year ago on Friday. People in the 20 finalist cities are looking for any sign of a winner.
docs.snippet: Amazon announced its plans for a second headquarters a year ago on Friday. People in the 20 finalist cities are looking for any sign of a winner.
docs.lead_paragraph: Over Labor Day weekend, a club promoter who goes by the name Purple posted a photo on Instagram from the LIV nightclub in Miami. In front of a wall graffitied with names and a single “Life Is Beautiful” sticker, Purple’s arm was casually draped over the shoulders of Jeff Bezos, the Amazon chief executive, whose pants matched the host’s name.

headline.main: The Mystery of Amazon HQ2 Has Finalists Seeing Clues Everywhere
headline.print_headline: Hunting for Clues for Amazon HQ2
